title-group.article-title: Biochemical, physiological and phenotypic variation in Ocimum Basilicum L. cultivars under salt stress conditions

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Basil (Ocimum basilicum L.), a globally significant medicinal plant of the Lamiaceae family, contains valuable volatile oils, polyphenols, and flavonoids with wide applications in food, pharmaceutical, and cosmetic industries. This study evaluated salinity stress responses across 13 basil cultivars, quantifying growth, morphological, and biochemical changes under 90 mM NaCl.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Salinity stress (90 mM NaCl) significantly reduced shoot biomass across all cultivars (p < 0.01), with Variegated showing maximum reduction (59.8%) versus Bush/Light Purple cultivars (31%). Essential oil content increased in all cultivars except Dark Opal under 90 mM NaCl (p = 0.003), with Lettuce showing a 12-fold rise (0.05–0.60% v/w), though yield (mL/plant) declined in most cultivars due to biomass reduction. Cluster analysis revealed genotype-specific tolerance mechanisms: Purple cultivars demonstrated specify osmotic adjustment through 58% higher proline accumulation and 33% lower MDA levels than sensitive genotypes.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Bush and Light Purple exhibited superior salt tolerance (31% biomass reduction), ideal for cultivation in saline soils, while Lettuce and Afghan showed enhanced essential oil production (up to 12-fold increase) under 90 mM NaCl, offering potential for phytochemical extraction. The observed diversity in stress responses provides valuable genetic resources for breeding climate-resilient cultivars, supporting sustainable medicinal plant production.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Basil (Ocimum basilicum L.), a globally valued medicinal plant of the Lamiaceae family, is renowned for its bioactive constituents, including volatile oils, polyphenols, and flavonoids, which underpin its applications in nutrition, pharmaceuticals, and cosmetics. Basil mucilage functions as a multifunctional hydrocolloid, exhibiting thickening, stabilizing, and emulsifying properties. This herb demonstrates significant therapeutic potential for a wide range of human ailments and disorders. Among its most notable pharmacological effects are its anti-cancer, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, immunomodulatory, anti-stress, antidiabetic, antipyretic, anti-arthritic, and antioxidant activities. Additionally, basil shows promise as a prophylactic agent and plays a beneficial role in cardiovascular disease management [1–4]. The volatile constituents of various basil organs, such as leaves, flowers, and seeds are mainly terpenes (monoterpenes, sesquiterpenes and diterpenes). Terpenoids are synthesized by specialized genes known as terpene synthases (TPS). Terpenes protect plants from biotic and abiotic stresses. They are used to attract insects for pollination and are used by humans for beneficial purposes as medicines, natural flavors, perfumes, and cosmetics [5].

Despite its economic importance, the cultivar-specific mechanisms driving Ocimum basilicum salt tolerance remain underexplored, hindering the development of resilient cultivars for saline environments [6]. Salinity impairs morpho-physiological processes, including ion homeostasis, osmotic balance, and photosynthesis, while triggering oxidative damage through reactive oxygen species (ROS) overproduction [7–9]. However, stress-induced modulation of secondary metabolites, such as essential oils and antioxidants, may enhance adaptive responses. Salinity stress is one of the most common abiotic stresses affecting the biosynthesis of active ingredients such as terpenoids and phenolic compounds in medicinal species. Salinity stress, by increasing ROS and stimulating defense pathways, causes the upregulation of secondary metabolism and the production of specific compounds. The relationships between ROS and secondary signaling messengers, which regulate the transcription of secondary metabolites, play an important role in plant response to salinity stress [10, 11]. Although the production of ROS such as OH, O2, and H2O2 and oxidative stress is possible due to the interaction of salinity stress with living systems, it should be borne in mind that ROS are also produced during natural biochemical reactions and act as cell signaling molecules for maintaining cellular homeostasis [10, 11].

Studies highlight species- and cultivar-specific responses to salinity. For instance, O. basilicum exhibits marked sensitivity to salt stress, with growth inhibition and altered biochemical profiles [12]. While salinity reduces biomass and chlorophyll content, it often elevates osmoprotectants (e.g., proline) and secondary metabolites in tolerant genotypes. For instance, Setayesh Mehr and Esmaeilzadeh (2013) reported elevated proline and phenolic compound levels in salt-stressed coriander, a mechanism linked to osmotic adjustment [13, 14]. Similarly, Corrado et al. (2021) demonstrated salinity-driven changes in basil’s polyphenols and antioxidant capacity, emphasizing genotype-dependent plasticity [15–18].

The mechanisms underlying salinity stress encompass several complex processes at both the cellular and physiological levels, which impact plant growth and performance [19–23]. In general, salinity stress stimulates the production of secondary compounds in medicinal plants, which play a crucial role in protecting plants against damage caused by chemical and physical stresses and enhancing their adaptation to saline conditions [24–28]. The adverse effects of salinity start with osmotic or water stress (a reduction in the root’s ability to absorb water), followed by ionic toxicity (nutritional imbalance, formation of ROS species), hormonal imbalance, and susceptibility to infection by the pathogen [29].

Despite these insights, gaps persist in understanding intra-specific variability in basil’s salt tolerance. This study investigates morpho-physiological and biochemical responses of 13 basil cultivars to 90 mM NaCl stress, addressing cultivar-specific resilience. The evaluation of such diversity highlights the potential for targeted breeding of salt-tolerant genotypes, supporting sustainable production nsuring food security and phytochemical production under adverse conditions.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: This research was conducted in 2023 and 2024 in the Laboratories-Research of Ilam University and the Medicinal Plants Department of Arak University. In this study, 13 basil cultivars were investigated from the Nazboo Company, Yazd, Iran, to determine the effects of salinity stress on various growth, morphological, and biochemical traits of different basil cultivars. The taxonomic identities of the Ocimum basilicum cultivars were authenticated by the Medicinal and Industrial Research Institute, Ardakan, Dr. R. Zareshahi, and deposited in the herbarium of the institute (voucher specimen no. SSU 0121–0133) (Table 1). All plant materials complied with institutional and international guidelines for experimental use of cultivated plants.

caption.p: Different cultivars used in the study

sec.title: Seed preparation and planting
sec.p: For each of the 13 seed cultivars, six pots were prepared for this study. A mixed cultivation medium was prepared from field soil, wind-blown sand, and manure with the proportions of 50% field soil, 30% rotted manure, and 20% wind-blown sand. To determine the physical and chemical properties of the soil, the experimental medium was analyzed (Table 2). We cultivated plants under controlled conditions (25/18°C day/night, 60% relative humidity, 14-h photoperiod, 300 µmol m− 2 s− 1 photosynthetically active radiation (PAR) from fluorescent lamps.

sec.title: Applying salinity stress
sec.p: The study employed a factorial experiment in a completely randomized design (CRD) with two factors: 13 cultivars and two salinity levels (0 mM [control] and 90 mM NaCl), replicated three times. Each cultivar × treatment combination had three pots, totaling 78 pots (13 cultivars × 2 treatments × 3 replications). Salinity stress was imposed using sodium chloride (NaCl) dissolved in irrigation water. At the four-leaf stage, plants were irrigated with 90 mM NaCl solution (1 L per pot) every 3 days for 45 days. To prevent salt accumulation, pots were flushed with distilled water every two weeks (1 L per pot). Electrical conductivity (EC) of the soil solution was maintained at 8.5–9.0 dS m− 1 for the saline group, while the control group received water with EC < 0.5 dS m− 1.

sec.title: Sampling and measuring traits
sec.p: Morphological traits of the plants were recorded before harvesting, which was conducted at the full-flowering stage. At this stage, 4 g from each sample was set aside for relevant experiments. These samples were frozen using liquid nitrogen and stored at -80 °C in a specialized freezer. Traits such as total fresh weight of the plant and total leaf weight were recorded, and plant organs were transferred to the laboratory for shade-drying, away from direct sunlight. Morphological parameters, including stem diameter, leaf length and width, petiole length, and inflorescence length, were measured using a digital caliper. Plant height was measured in centimeters using a ruler. Fresh and dry weights of both aerial and underground parts were determined using a digital scale with a precision of 0.01 g. Following the measurement of growth and morphological traits, physiological and biochemical parameters—such as relative water content (RWC), electrolyte leakage (EL), chlorophyll, carotenoids, malondialdehyde (MDA), proline, and essential oil yield—were assessed according to standard protocols.

sec.title: Relative water content
sec.p: Where FW is fresh weight, DW is dry weight, and TW is turgid weight [30].

sec.title: Electrolyte leakage
Chlorophyll and carotenoids
sec.p: Chlorophyll and carotenoids were extracted from 0.5 g fresh leaf tissue in 15 mL 80% acetone, homogenized in the dark, and centrifuged at 6,000 rpm for 10 min. Absorbance was measured at 663, 646, and 470 nm. Concentrations were calculated using Lichtenthaler and Wellburn [32].

sec.title: Proline
sec.p: To measure the free proline content in leaves, 0.2 g of fresh plant samples were homogenized in 3% sulfosalicylic acid [33]. The reaction mixture, which contained 2 mL of the resulting extract, 2 mL of ninhydrin reagent, and 2 mL of glacial acetic acid, was placed in a water bath at 100 °C for one hour. The test tubes were immediately placed on ice. The mixture was extracted with 4 mL of toluene, then the supernatant containing proline soluble in toluene was separated and read in a spectrophotometer at a wavelength of 520 nm. Proline concentration was determined against a standard curve (0–100 µg/mL) prepared with L-proline (Sigma-Aldrich). Absorbance at 520 nm was plotted against known concentrations for quantification.

sec.title: Malondialdehyde
sec.p: First, 0.2 g of fresh leaf tissue was thoroughly ground and homogenized with 5 mL of 0.1% (w/v) trichloroacetic acid in a porcelain mortar and centrifuged for 20 min at 10,000 rpm. To measure malondialdehyde (MDA) content, 1 mL of the supernatant was mixed with 4 mL of 20% trichloroacetic acid containing 0.5% (w/v) thiobarbituric acid. The mixture was incubated in a 90 °C water bath for 30 min, then immediately cooled in an ice bath for 30 min to stop the reaction. After centrifugation at 10,000 × g for 10 min at 4 °C, absorbance was measured at 532 nm and 600 nm using a spectrophotometer. MDA content (nmol g− 1 FW) was calculated as:
where Vtotal is the total extract volume (mL), ε is the extinction coefficient (155 mM− 1 cm− 1), and W is the sample fresh weight (g) [33].

sec.title: Essential oil extraction
sec.p: The dried aerial parts of cultivars were subjected to the extraction of essential oils by hydro-distillation technique using a Clevenger-type apparatus (European Pharmacopoeia) for 3 h. Three repetitions were designed for all cultivars, with 30 g of aerial parts samples crushed. 450 ml of water was added to the flask before the extraction process began. The essential oil content (% v/w and essential oil yield (mL/plant) were measured [34].

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analysis was conducted using a two-way ANOVA in SAS version 9.4 (SAS Institute Inc., Cary, NC, USA) to assess the effects of cultivar, salinity, and their interaction as fixed factors. Post-hoc mean separation was performed with Duncan’s multiple range test at (p < 0.01). For multivariate analyses, R software v3.4.3 (https://www.r-project.org) was utilized with the following packages: FactoMineR for principal component analysis (PCA), pheatmap for heatmap visualization, and corrplot for Pearson correlation matrices. All instruments, including the LI-6800 spectrophotometer used for chlorophyll quantification (calibrated at 663/646 nm in May 2023), were validated prior to data collection to ensure measurement consistency.

sec.title: Growth and morphological parameters
sec.p: The results of the analysis of variance showed that the interaction between salinity stress and different cultivars on morphological parameters was significant (p < 0.05) (Table 3). Table 4 presents mean comparisons of morphological parameters, under 0 mM and 90 mM NaCl. Reductions are calculated as [(Control – Stress)/Control] × 100, with statistical significance assessed via Duncan’s test (p < 0.05). The cultivar × salinity interaction significantly affected plant height (F₁₂,₅₂ = 17.52, p = 0.021), with Bush cultivar showing the largest decline (Fig. 1). Salinity stress significantly reduced plant height across all cultivars (Table 3), with the most pronounced decline in Bush and Lemon cultivars (35%). Conversely, Lettuce exhibited remarkable resilience, showing only a 9% reduction (Fig. 1). Notably, Violetto uniquely increased leaf dimensions under stress, suggesting potential adaptive mechanisms (Table 4). The highest leaf length in the control conditions was for the Genovese and Amethyst cultivars (8 cm), and the lowest value was observed in the bush cultivar (3.5 cm). The highest and lowest reduction in leaf length changes under stress conditions compared to the control were observed in the Bush type (60%) and Afghan (10.4%) cultivars, respectively. The highest and lowest leaf widths were observed in the Genovese (5.3 cm) and Bush-type (1.3 cm) cultivars, respectively. The highest and lowest leaf width changes were observed in the Bush type (42.5%) and Dark opal (7.4%) cultivars, respectively. Stem diameter decreased in all cultivars under salt stress compared to control plants. The highest and lowest stem diameters were recorded for the Cinnamon (4.7 mm) and Dark opal (2.5 mm) cultivars, respectively (Table 4). Shoot fresh weight declined across all cultivars under 90 mM NaCl stress relative to controls (p < 0.01). Salinity stress reduced shoot fresh weight across cultivars, with Purpurascens (182 g) and Amethyst (68 g) showing the highest and lowest values, respectively. Variegated exhibited the greatest shoot dry weight reduction (59.8%, p = 0.007; Fig. 2), while Bush and Light Purple showed minimal biomass reductions (19% for total biomass dry weight, 31% for shoot dry weight; Figs. 2 and 3, and Table 4). Root fresh weight decreased in all basil cultivars under salt stress. The highest and lowest root fresh weights were related to the Genovese (125 g) and Bush-type cultivars (23 g), respectively. The highest and lowest changes in root weight reduction under stress conditions compared to the control were observed in Variegated (79%) and Purpurascens (18%) cultivars, respectively (Table 4). Shoot dry weight decreased in all 13 studied cultivars under salt stress. The highest amount of shoot dry weight was observed in the Purpurascens and Lettuce cultivars (31 g), and the lowest amount was observed in the Amethyst cultivar (8.5 g). The highest changes in shoot dry weight were observed in the Variegated cultivar (59.8%), and the lowest changes were observed in the Bush type and Amethyst cultivars (31%) (Fig. 2). Variegated exhibited the greatest shoot dry weight reduction (59.8%, p = 0.007; Fig. 2), while Bush and Light Purple showed minimal biomass reductions (19% for total biomass dry weight, p < 0.05; 31% for shoot dry weight, p < 0.05; Figs. 2 and 3, and Table 4).

sec.p: The dry weight of roots in all basil cultivars decreased under salt stress compared to the control, with the highest amount of dry weight of roots in the Genovese and Variegated cultivars (11.5 g) and the lowest amount in the Bush type cultivar (4.5 g). (Table 4). Variegated cultivars showed 59.8% biomass reduction (p = 0.007, 95% CI). The dry weight of total biomass decreased in all basil cultivars under salt stress, with the highest and lowest dry weight of biomass being in the Variegated cultivars (331 g) and Amethyst cultivars (148 g), respectively. The highest and lowest changes in dry weight of biomass were observed in the Variegated (54%) and Bush type cultivars (19%), respectively (Fig. 3).

sec.title: Physiological and biochemical parameters
sec.p: The results of the analysis of variance table showed that the interaction between salinity stress and different cultivars on physiological and biochemical parameters was significant (p < 0.05) (Table 5). Analysis of variance of the data related to RWC showed that all basil cultivars were significantly affected by salt stress (Table 5). RWC in all basil cultivars decreased under salt stress compared to control plants. The highest and lowest RWC in control plants were reported in lettuce (98%) and Amethyst (36%), respectively. Lettuce maintained exceptionally high RWC (98%) under control, likely due to its robust water retention traits, which declined only marginally under stress (4% reduction) (Table 6).

sec.p: The amount of electrolyte leakage increased in all basil cultivars under salt stress compared to control plants. Electrolyte leakage increased under 90 mM NaCl, with Amethyst showing the highest rise (36.2% under control to 91.6% under stress; Table 6). Proline concentration increased in all basil cultivars under salt stress compared to control plants. The highest and lowest proline concentrations in control plants were observed in the cultivars Amethyst (0.96 mg/g FW) and Lettuce (0.09 mg/g FW), respectively. The highest and lowest shifts in proline increase under salt stress compared to the control were reported in the cultivars Green (58%) and Afghan (11%) (Fig. 4).

caption.p: Mean comparison of proline content in 13 Ocimum basilicum cultivars under 90 mM NaCl stress versus control (0 mM NaCl). Bars represent means ± SE (n = 3); letters indicate significant differences (p < 0.05, Duncan’s test)

sec.p: Lipid peroxidation (malondialdehyde) increased in all basil cultivars under salt stress compared to control plants. The highest and lowest malondialdehyde levels in control plants were reported in the cultivars Amethyst (1.1 nmol g− 1 FW) and Lettuce (0.25 nmol g⁻¹ FW), respectively. The highest amount of malondialdehyde under salt stress conditions compared to the control was observed in Violetto and Variegated cultivars (33%), and the lowest amount of malondialdehyde under salt stress conditions compared to the control was observed in Lemon and Purpurascens cultivars (8%) (Table 6).

Salt stress showed a significant effect (p < 0.05) on the amount of chlorophyll a, b, total, and carotenoids in different basil cultivars (Table 5). The amount of chlorophylls, total chlorophyll, and carotenoids in the leaves of all cultivars with salt stress decreased compared to the control plants. Total chlorophyll ranged from 11.9 mg/g FW (Amethyst) to 19.5 mg/g FW (Lettuce) under control, declining by 4.5–11% under stress (Table 7). Under non-stress conditions, the carotenoid content was the highest in lettuce (3.8 mg/g FW) and lowest in Purpurascens ruby ​​(2.8 mg/g FW) cultivars. Also, the highest and lowest changes in carotenoid content were observed in Genovese (12%) and Cinnamon (2.5%) cultivars, respectively (Table 6). The cultivar × salinity interaction profoundly affected essential oil content (F₁₂,₅₂ = 6.84, p = 0.003), emphasizing genotype-driven responses (Table 3). The Essential oil content increased in all cultivars except Dark Opal under 90 mM NaCl (p = 0.003). Essential oil content increased 12-fold in Lettuce (0.05–0.60% v/w) under 90 mM NaCl stress, while Dark Opal showed a 50% reduction (Fig. 5; Table 6). However, essential oil yield (mL/plant) declined in most cultivars except Lettuce (7.4-fold increase) due to biomass reduction (Table 6). The highest and lowest essential oil yield under non-salt stress conditions were observed in Afghan (0.11 mL/cultivar) and Lettuce (0.016 mL/cultivar), respectively. The highest and lowest changes in essential oil yield under salt stress conditions compared to the control were observed in Lettuce (7.4 times) and Cinnamon (1.1 times), respectively. While the highest and lowest changes in essential oil yield under saline conditions compared to the control were observed in Dark opal (0.3 times) and Bush (1 time), respectively (Table 6).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Morphological declines (e.g., 59.8% biomass loss in Variegated) paralleled biochemical shifts, including elevated MDA (33% in Violetto) and reduced chlorophyll (Table 6), illustrating multi-level salinity impacts. Salinity stress significantly impacted plant morphology across all cultivars. Notably, Bush and Lemon cultivars experienced the most drastic reduction in plant height (35%), while Lettuce demonstrated resilience with a mere 9% decline (Fig. 1). This variability underscores cultivar-specific tolerance mechanisms. For instance, the robust performance of Lettuce may stem from enhanced osmoregulation, a hypothesis supported by its minimal electrolyte leakage (Table 6). Intriguingly, Violetto exhibited a unique response: leaf length and width increased by 12.3% and 9.3%, respectively, under stress (Table 4). This contrasts with trends in other cultivars, where leaf dimensions declined. Such divergence suggests Violetto might reallocate resources to maintain photosynthetic efficiency, a potential adaptive strategy warranting further genomic analysis. Total biomass dry weight plummeted by 54% in Variegated, the most affected cultivar, whereas Bush showed only a 19% reduction (Fig. 3). These results highlight a trade-off between growth and stress tolerance, with Bush and Light Purple prioritizing survival through reduced biomass loss (19–31%) and enhanced proline accumulation (up to 58%), potentially mediated by P5CS gene upregulation.

Salinity stress inhibits cell development in higher plants by disrupting water transport within vascular tissues [35]. Under salinity stress, the intensity, duration, and timing of the stress, along with the plant’s response after stress removal and the interaction between salinity and other factors, are of considerable importance [36]. Among the most apparent effects of salinity stress on plants are reductions in plant growth and height. Salinity stress can suppress growth by inhibiting water uptake, impairing cell division and elongation, obstructing the transport of storage materials, suppressing the synthesis of hormones and nutrients, and inducing toxicity. Under saline conditions, the uptake of essential nutrients, including nitrogen, is significantly decreased, thereby reducing plant growth. Salinity reduces water uptake, consequently limiting plant growth through physiological disruptions [37–39]. The inhibitory effects of salt stress are influenced by factors including salt concentration, duration of exposure, plant species and varieties, photochemical quenching ability, plant developmental stages, type of stress, gas exchange characteristics, and levels of photosynthetic pigments [29].

Our data reveal cultivar-specific growth reductions under salinity (e.g., Bush: 35% height loss vs. Lettuce: 9%; Fig. 1), aligning with turgor-driven cell expansion inhibition [35]. Notably, Lettuce’s resilience mirrors Artemisia annua’s osmoregulatory adaptations [39], suggesting shared tolerance mechanisms like vacuolar Na⁺ sequestration. Although the growth of all basil cultivars under salinity stress was significantly lower than under normal conditions, some cultivars were more severely affected due to physiological differences, resulting in greater reductions in growth and yield. Similar findings have been reported in stressed populations of certain medicinal plants, such as Artemisia annua [39]. Stress reduces plant growth by adversely affecting photosynthesis [40]. Under salinity stress, root development is restricted during various stages of plant growth. To employ avoidance mechanisms, the plant must maintain low salt concentrations within the cytoplasm, which leads to corky and restricted root development, ultimately decreasing growth, root length, and both fresh and dry biomass [41]. Excessive salt uptake has also been reported to reduce plant growth and productivity due to premature aging, which results from diminished photosynthetic enzymatic activity in the Calvin cycle. Ion toxicity, particularly due to the excessive presence of Na⁺ and the imbalance of mineral nutrients, is a principal factor limiting plant growth and productivity [42].

The results indicated that most vegetative traits were influenced by salinity stress. Given that the highest concentration of essential oil is found in the inflorescence and leaf parts of this plant, the flower and leaf traits are crucial in its breeding programs. These traits are also of significant importance in the selection and enhancement of superior cultivars for nutritional purposes. Research has demonstrated that salinity stress negatively impacts the vegetative growth of medicinal plants [43]. These findings are also consistent with those of other studies [44, 45]. Salinity leads to a substantial reduction in the weight of basil shoots. This reduction in shoot weight can be attributed to the decreased photosynthesis. The decline in photosynthesis under salinity stress results from stomatal closure, reduced leaf area, or diminished protoplasmic activity [1, 2, 14].

Salinity stress resulted in a decrease in the relative water content (RWC) of leaves in the studied cultivars. The relative water content of leaves indicates the water uptake by tissues and cells and is a reliable method for measuring osmotic stress in plants. Relative water content reflects metabolic activities in plant tissues, and salinity-tolerant plants have a higher ability to absorb protoplast water and retain more water. Therefore, they have higher RWC values [46–48]. In this study, salinity stress led to a decrease in RWC in the studied cultivars. However, the results obtained from this study showed that the Amethyst cultivar had a lower RWC under stress conditions compared to the other cultivars studied, which indicates a lower ability of this cultivar to reduce water loss under stress conditions or a decrease in the ability of this cultivar to absorb water. Amethyst’s low RWC (36% under stress; Table 6) correlates with its severe electrolyte leakage (87%), implicating membrane instability. Conversely, Lettuce’s minimal RWC loss (4%) aligns with its proline surge (Fig. 4), suggesting osmoprotectant-driven water retention. The results of this experiment on RWC parameter are consistent with previous studies on the medicinal plants Dracocephalum moldavica [49] and Matricaria chamomilla L [50].

Electrolyte leakage is considered an indicator of membrane stability and increases during salt stress [51]. The cultivar Amethyst had more electrolyte leakage compared to the other cultivars studied, indicating a lower ability of this cultivar. Studies have shown that salt stress increased electrolyte leakage in the Ocimum basilicum [52], which is consistent with the results of this study.

Proline, an amino acid compound and a powerful antioxidant that inhibits programmed cell death, plays a crucial role in enhancing stress resistance in plants [53]. A positive correlation between proline accumulation and salt stress resistance has been documented in numerous plant species. The increase in proline content with rising stress intensity highlights the significance of proline in alleviating stress across various plants [54]. Furthermore, the accumulation of proline in stressed cultivars as an osmolyte can enhance water uptake. One possible reason for the higher relative water content (RWC) in these cultivars may be the increased proline under stress conditions [55]. The 58% proline increase in Green cultivar (Fig. 4) mirrors findings in salt-stressed Arabidopsis [2], highlighting conserved osmoprotectant pathways. Proline levels increased significantly under 90 mM NaCl (p < 0.01), with Green showing a 58% rise (0.09 to 0.14 mg/g FW; Fig. 4). This increase correlated negatively with MDA (r = -0.62, p < 0.05), indicating proline’s role in ROS scavenging and membrane protection. Therefore, the Purpurascens ruby cultivar, which is sensitive, along with the lettuce and Purpurascens cultivars, can be considered among the resistant cultivars.

As a key indicator for assessing oxidative damage and evaluating the stability and integrity of the cell membrane, lipid peroxidation is among the most critical physiological parameters used to determine the extent of damage and degradation in plant cell membranes under salt stress. Its levels vary depending on the plant species and their stress resistance. In the present study, malondialdehyde (MDA) content was low under control conditions but increased significantly under stress, indicating reduced cellular stability and viability in response to salt stress. Both malondialdehyde content and ion leakage rose under stress conditions across all studied basil cultivars. Among them, the Amethyst cultivar was identified as susceptible, while the Purpurascens and Lettuce cultivars demonstrated resistance. Notably, cultivars exhibiting smaller increases in malondialdehyde content were more capable of tolerating salt stress. The findings of this study, along with evidence from related research, suggest that lipid peroxidation leads to increased membrane fluidity, ultimately elevating cell membrane permeability. Salt-sensitive cultivars display a more pronounced increase in membrane peroxidation under stress compared to resistant ones.

Chlorophyll content and photosynthetic pigments are among the most crucial factors influencing the photosynthetic capacity of plants, as they directly determine the rate and magnitude of photosynthesis and subsequent biomass production. Reductions or stability in chlorophyll content during oxidative stress are influenced by the duration and intensity of stress, as well as species-specific responses. Resistant cultivars tend to exhibit smaller reductions in chlorophyll levels compared to sensitive cultivars, with the Lettuce and Purpurascens varieties being resistant, and the Amethyst cultivar showing sensitivity. Furthermore, salinity stress increases the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in chloroplasts, leading to damage to the chloroplast membrane [51–55]. Previous studies have demonstrated that salt stress reduces heterophyll content in basil [55], clary sage (Salvia sclarea) [56], fenugreek (Trigonella foenum-graecum) [41], and savory (Satureja hortensis) [58], findings that align with the results of the current study.

The high percentage of essential oil under stress conditions can be attributed to the reduction in leaf area, which subsequently leads to the increased density of essential oil-secreting glands. Additionally, the increase in essential oil content in plants under salt stress may result from changes in primary metabolites caused by salinity, which, in turn, leads to the production of intermediate compounds necessary for the synthesis of secondary metabolites [59]. The biosynthesis of essential oils occurs in two different ways: either in the mevalonate pathway (MVA), which is active in the cytosol, or in the methylerythritol-4-phosphate pathway (MEP) that is activated within the plastid. Both pathways lead to the formation of isoprenoid units (C5) as a structural isopentyl-diphosphate (IDP) unit and its isomer, Dimethylallyl pyrophosphate (DMADP), which is considered the foundational pattern for the synthesis of essential oils. Different studies have shown that the synthesis of some compounds is fulfilled through the MVA pathway, while the majority of essential oil compounds of basil belong to the class of monoterpenes, which are synthesized in the plastid through the MEP pathway. It appears that stress directs biosynthesis towards the MEP pathway, and blocking the MVA pathway would lead to maximum production of essential oil. Studies have indicated that the MVA synthesis pathway can be blocked by Mevinolin, a statin that acts as a specific inhibitor of the HMGCR key enzyme in the MVA pathway. In fact, mevinolin halts the synthesis of terpenoids in the cytosol, but not in plastids. This difference may be related to the role of salinity stress in sugar metabolism and nucleic acids, activator and cofactor of different enzyme classes, and regulation of gene expression [5, 60–62].

Changes in essential oil content under stress conditions remain a challenging and two-dimensional issue that can vary depending on the type of species or cultivar and the level of stress. Therefore, contrary to the present study, salt stress has caused a decrease in essential oil production in some medicinal species such as peppermint [63], lavender [64], and basil [65], which can be attributed to a decrease in the level of photosynthesizers (due to increased membrane peroxidation and, consequently, an increase in malondialdehyde). Because essential oils are from the chemical group of terpenes and because glucose is a suitable precursor in the synthesis of essential oils, especially monoterpenes, photosynthesis and the production of photosynthetic products are directly related to essential oil production [66]. Lettuce’s 12-fold essential oil content increase (0.05–0.60% v/w) under 90 mM NaCl, coupled with minimal RWC reduction (4%), suggests synergistic osmoprotectant and terpenoid pathway activation, potentially driven by upregulated TPS gene expression. in fact, the issue suggest osmoprotectant and terpenoid pathway activation, possibly via upregulated TPS genes. Dark Opal’s 50% reduction (Fig. 5) indicates metabolic disruption. While reduced photosynthesis often lowers EO [66], Lettuce’s retained chlorophyll (Table 6) may sustain precursor supply, echoing stress-induced monoterpene upregulation [18]. Also, the decrease in essential oil production can be attributed to the greater energy expenditure in the plant to absorb water under stress conditions, changes and increases in protoplast concentration, changes in respiratory pathways and the relevant pentose phosphate pathway, which somehow disrupt the production of essential oil-producing enzymes in the plant and consequently reduce essential oil production. Some studies have shown that the decrease in essential oil in basil cultivars is associated with low vegetative growth; thus, some cultivars entered the flowering stage earlier. Accordingly, the highest amount of basil essential oil is observed in late vegetative growth and early flowering, and the amount of essential oil is directly related to plant growth (biomass amount). Given that basil plants have the highest amount of essential oil at the beginning of the full flowering stage, the low number of flowering plants and the failure of plants to reach the flowering stage can also explain the low percentage of essential oil in plants under salt stress treatment [67].The results of all studies show that under stress conditions, terpenoids, as a major component, play a fundamental and key role in the defense responses of medicinal plants and subsequently the synthesis of pharmaceutically active compounds (PhACs) and aroma constituents. The synthesis rate of terpenoids under stress conditions is regulated by genes related to terpene synthases (TPS). In the biosynthetic pathway of terpenoids, TPS is positioned at the branch point and is a key enzyme for terpenoids biosynthesis. However least number of TPS genes were characterized in Ocimum species [5, 60–62]. Although this study did not include enzymatic or transcriptomic analyses, limiting insights into molecular mechanisms. Lettuce’s 12-fold essential oil increase suggests enhanced TPS expression via the MEP pathway, necessitating future transcriptomic and metabolomic validation.

The strong MDA-biomass inverse correlation (r = − 0.82; Fig. 6) underscores oxidative damage’s growth penalty. PCA further segregates stress-adapted cultivars (Lettuce, Violetto) via proline/EO loadings (Fig. 7), highlighting multi-trait selection potential. Principal Component Analysis (Fig. 7) revealed two distinct clusters: stress-adapted cultivars (e.g., Lettuce, Violetto) and stress-sensitive ones (e.g., Amethyst, Dark Opal). Proline and MDA loaded strongly on PC1, explaining 42% of variance, while chlorophyll and biomass dominated PC2 (28%).

sec.p: The results of the correlation of the studied traits in different basil cultivars showed that there is a positive correlation between growth-morphological parameters (height, leaf length, leaf width, stem diameter, fresh weight of shoots, roots, leaves, biomass, dry weight of shoots, roots, leaves, biomass, petiole length, number of side branches, inflorescence length, leaf area). Specifically, there was a positive correlation between plant height and inflorescence length, leaf length and width, petiole length, and fresh and dry weight of the plant. The increase in inflorescence length was associated with an increase in productive traits and traits related to leaves. Also, a positive correlation was observed between biochemical parameters (proline, malondialdehyde, electrolyte leakage and essential oil yield). Significant correlations between morphological and biochemical parameters should be presented and discussed in a few lines. Figure 7 shows the distribution of the studied traits on the coordinate axis using the first and second factors.

Finally, to identify and group the genotypes, cluster analysis was conducted using the Ward method and the squared Euclidean distance criterion based on the studied traits (Fig. 8). Violetto’s genetic distance in clustering (Fig. 8) reflects its unique leaf expansion under stress (Table 4), positioning it as a candidate for introgression breeding. Contrastingly, Amethyst’s susceptibility mirrors its biochemical dysregulation (e.g., MDA, EL). The results of the cluster analysis of the cultivars showed that their placement in different clusters did not exhibit a justifiable or consistent relationship with their normal and stress conditions. Cultivars under stress and non-stress conditions were not consistently grouped into similar clusters, indicating the high diversity among the cultivars and their varying levels of tolerance and responses to stress. This outcome suggests that differences observed among cultivars under non-stress conditions did not ensure the preservation of their morpho-chemical characteristics under stress, resulting in varying tolerance levels and the emergence of a new range of cultivars. The results of the cluster analysis in the present study also revealed that the cultivars ‘Violetta’ and ‘Variegated’, which showed the greatest genetic distance, could be considered suitable candidates for crossing in breeding programs.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The medicinal plant basil is a strategic species that, in addition to its nutritional value, is also utilized in the pharmaceutical, food, and health industries. This study elucidates cultivar-specific salt tolerance in Ocimum basilicum, identifying Bush and Light Purple as resilient candidates for saline agriculture (31% biomass reduction) and Lettuce and Afghan as high essential oil producers (up to 12-fold increase) under 90 mM NaCl. These findings inform marker-assisted breeding for arid regions. Future multi-omics studies (transcriptomics, metabolomics) should target TPS and P5CS expression to unravel stress-responsive pathways. The results indicate a direct negative impact of salinity on growth and biomass across different levels, reflecting the varying tolerance among cultivars. Salinity tolerance in basil is cultivar-specific: Lettuce’s minimal growth loss (9% height), 12× EO surge, and proline-driven RWC stability contrast with Amethyst’s susceptibility (21% RWC drop, 87% EL). These traits define a resilience phenotype exploitable for arid-region breeding. In addition to the effects on morphological traits and biomass yield, the findings also reveal changes in biochemical properties. These fluctuations highlight the capacity of different cultivars to adapt to stress conditions and synthesize chemical compounds and secondary metabolites. Overall, the results of this study confirm that basil cultivars exhibit various responses to salinity, which can serve as a basis for identifying cultivars with greater salinity tolerance. These findings underscore that selecting salinity-tolerant cultivars improves yield under challenging environmental conditions. The study also revealed substantial diversity in morphological and biochemical traits among basil cultivars; therefore, depending on the objective, valuable cultivars can be identified as suitable genetic resources for breeding, production, and processing purposes. Future research is recommended to explore the effects of varying salinity levels and to conduct genomic analyses of salinity-tolerant cultivars. We propose Lettuce and Violetto as elite germplasm for production in saline areas due to EO yield stability (± 7.4× increase) and biomass retention. Their transcriptomic profiling (e.g., P5CS, NHX1) could unravel novel tolerance genes. Future studies should resolve Lettuce’s EO-stress paradox via terpene synthase expression assays and in silico promoter analysis of ABA-responsive elements (ABREs), leveraging genome data from O. basilicum.
